stem: A client with Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH) is being treated with fluid restriction. Based on the documentation in the Serial Hyponatremia & Neuro-Metabolic Log, which action is the highest priority?

options.text: Initiate 3% hypertonic saline through a central venous catheter.
Enforce strict bed rest with all four side rails up.
Offer the client sugar-free hard candy to relieve extreme thirst.
Educate the client on the importance of limiting water intake.

rationale.correct: The client has severe, symptomatic hyponatremia (Na+ 118 mEq/L) and is showing signs of cerebral edema (headache, twitching, confusion). The highest priority is to initiate 3% hypertonic saline (a1). This hypertonic solution shifts water out of brain cells and into the vascular space, reducing intracranial pressure and preventing seizures. It should be infused slowly, ideally via a central line, due to its high osmolarity.
clinicalPearls: In SIADH, hyponatremia is dilutional due to excessive water retention.
Serum sodium levels < 120 mEq/L indicate a high risk for seizure or coma.
Rapid correction of hyponatremia can lead to central pontine myelinolysis (permanent brain stem damage). Sodium correction must be slow and carefully monitored.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: While seizure precautions are important, they do not address the underlying cause of cerebral edema. Education is not the priority during a critical neurological decline. The priority is to correct the hyponatremia.

mnemonic.title: S-I-A-D-H
mnemonic.expansion: S-Sodium is low. I-Increased Intracranial Pressure. A-Assess neurological status. D-Danger level < 120 mEq/L. H-Hypertonic Saline (3%).

exhibits.content:

2. Seizure precautions.
3. Administer 3% hypertonic saline at 30 mL/hr if Na+ < 120 mEq/L.
